markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

pilotonline.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of The Virginian-Pilot, a daily newspaper based in Norfolk, Virginia.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership or Financing

The Pilot is owned by Tribune Publishing Company, a publicly traded, Chicago-based media and publishing company formerly known as Tronc Inc. Tribune owns newspapers and publications in major markets, including The Baltimore Sun, New York Daily News, Orlando Sentinel, and its flagship publication, the Chicago Tribune.

Tribune generates its revenue through advertising and subscriptions for its printed and digital products. Its publications have won numerous awards, including a Pulitzer Prize in 2017.

Content

The site covers local government, sports, business, and lifestyle for the South Hampton Roads region in southeastern Virginia, which includes Virginia Beach and Norfolk. Most coverage is through written articles, but the site also features photo galleries and video stories.

Pilotonline.com publishes several special sections, such as Caring for the Aging, targeting seniors and their caregivers, and Summer Camp Guide, enabling parents to browse camp listings. The site also offers a seven-part podcast called The Shot, reporting on an unsolved murder of a policeman in the area. The Associated Press supplies some national stories. An electronic edition of the print newspaper is available.

Credibili

Headlines and articles are written with a neutral tone that appropriately reflects the story’s content. Stories cite multiple sources, including experts and firsthand accounts. The site has a Corrections page that lists stories that have been updated or corrected, and the Contact Us page encourages readers to submit corrections.

In 2018, reporter Tim Eberly was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting on Virginia’s “three strikes law,” which denied some felons the opportunity for parole. As a result, the state parole board changed how it interprets the law. The newspaper has won three other Pulitzer Prizes.

Transparency

The site names its owners, editors, and writers on either a staff page or an About page describing the newspaper. Stories usually contain the reporter’s byline, phone number, and email address, and link to a biography page. Editorial pieces are only credited to Virginian-Pilot. Short biographies, phone numbers, and emails are all listed along with reporters’ bylines.

Advertisements are clearly labeled.

History

The publication was founded in 1865. It was acquired by Tronc in 2018.

The Virginian-Pilot won Pulitzer Prizes in 1985, for general news reporting that exposed corruption of a local economic development official; in 1960, for editorial writing for a series of editorials on school integration; and in 1929, for editorial writing. The newspaper was a finalist in 2007 for the explanatory reporting prize for an examination of the U.S’ reliance on private military personnel.

Correction: An earlier version of this label erroneously reported that The Virginian-Pilot won a Pulitzer Prize in 2007. The newspaper was a finalist for the prize that year.

Written by:
David Wolinsky

Edited by:
Sarah Brandt Amy Westfeldt
